Homage to the Bodhisattva Boundless Vision
Homage to the Bodhisattva Unimpeded Vision. I take refuge in the innumerable and boundless great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the worlds of the ten directions.
I respectfully pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.

Homage to the pratyekabuddhas who have ended arrogance, to the pratyekabuddhas who are intimate, to the pratyekabuddhas who have attained liberation, to the pratyekabuddhas who are immaculate, to the pratyekabuddhas who are solitary, to the pratyekabuddhas who are like roosters, to the pratyekabuddhas who can create arrogance, to the pratyekabuddhas who have regressed, to the pratyekabuddhas who do not regress, and to the pratyekabuddhas who investigate. I take refuge in the innumerable and boundless pratyekabuddhas such as these.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
Repent with utmost sincerity of the offenses of greed and desire.
The sÅ«tras say:
Simply because of greed and desire, one is imprisoned in the prison of delusion, drowning in the river of birth and death, unable to escape.

Sentient beings, because of these five desires, have been transmigrating in birth and death since the past. The bones accumulated by each sentient being in one eon are like Mount Vipula in RÄjagá¹›ha, and the mother's milk they have drunk is like the four great oceans, and the blood shed from their bodies exceeds this.

Parents, siblings, and relatives, crying and shedding tears like the four great oceans when their lives end. Therefore it is said: Where there is love, there is birth; where love ends, there is extinction. Therefore, know that birth and death have craving and love as their basis.
The reason the sÅ«tra says:

The sin of sexual desire can cause sentient beings to fall into the hells and hungry ghosts to suffer. If in the animal realm, they will receive the bodies of doves, sparrows, mandarin ducks, and so forth. If born among humans, their wives will not be chaste and they will not obtain the retinue they desire. Since sexual desire has such evil karma,
therefore, disciples!
Today, with utmost sincerity, I bow my head and take refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha Lion's Voice in the East, Homage to the Buddha Great Cloud Treasury in the South, Homage to the Buddha Immeasurable Life in the West, Homage to the Buddha Red Lotus Light in the North, Homage to the Buddha Stainless Lapis Lazuli in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha Supreme Taming in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha Scattered Flowers and Born Virtues in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha Mind Equal to Space in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha Stainless Renown in the Underworld, Homage to the Buddha Pure Wisdom Ocean in the Upper Regions. We take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space.

Disciples, from beginningless time until now, we have either had affairs with other people's wives and concubines, stolen other people's women, violated the chastity of others, defiled bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, broken others' pure conduct, forced others into improper acts, looked at others with impure thoughts, made lewd remarks, or even slandered others' families and defiled the good names of the virtuous. We have also engaged in impure acts with men and the five kinds of people.
Such offenses are innumerable and boundless. Today, we sincerely take refuge and repent.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, whether receiving a female body or a male body, our minds are like wild horses, always unrestrained and never still for a moment, always harboring evil thoughts and constantly giving rise to lustful desires;
Or, in the assembly of the monastery, we have no intention of listening to the Dharma, our eyes always greedily gazing;

Or, we love lustful monks who destroy other men, do not give birth to the Buddha's teachings, and indulge in lustful desires, causing our minds to be scattered in the great ocean and completely lose our way;
Or, we defile the monks' three robes and Dharma robes;
Or, in the monastery compound, we engage in impure conduct and touch each other.
Such offenses are innumerable and boundless. Today, we repent with a sense of shame and a sincere mind.
Moreover, disciples!
From beginningless time until today, whether in a female body or a male body, we always harbor lustful desires;
Or, we encroach on and steal others' husbands and wives, and seduce various men.

Or using talismans, spells, curses, and witchcraft to send illnesses to others' wives, people have little blessings and are possessed by the deviant, and various illness-causing ghosts take advantage of this, not encountering good doctors and eventually causing their own death.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with shame and remorse, we confess and repent. We sincerely bow our heads and take refuge in repentance.
Furthermore, disciples!
From beginningless time until today, we have either used the eyes to be attracted to colors, or to be infatuated with dark yellow, red, purple, precious adornments, and rare treasures;
Or to grasp the characteristics of men and women's height, shortness, blackness, whiteness, and graceful manner, giving rise to improper thoughts;
Or the ears have greedily pursued beautiful sounds, such as palace,å•†, and stringed instruments, music, and singing;
Or to grasp the characteristics of men and women's voices, speech, crying, and laughter, giving rise to improper thoughts;
Or the nose has relied on famous fragrances, such as musk, orchid, and saffron, to give rise to improper thoughts;

Or the tongue craves delicious flavors, fresh and tender, sweet and fatty, using the flesh and blood of sentient beings to nourish the four elements, further hating the source of suffering and giving rise to thoughts of non-dharma;
Or the body enjoys colorful brocades and silks, all soft and smooth, and the gorgeous robes of the seven treasures, giving rise to thoughts of non-dharma;
Or the mind has many confused thoughts that go against the Dharma, giving rise to these six thoughts and creating grave offenses.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge and repent before the Buddhas, the supreme Dharma, and the noble Sangha in the ten directions.

May the disciples, by repenting of the offenses of sexual desire and so forth, give rise to merits and virtues. May they be born in every life through spontaneous transformation, not by womb. May they be pure and radiant, with the marks and radiance of excellence. May their six faculties be clear and bright, their wisdom sharp and discerning. May they thoroughly understand that affection is like shackles and chains, and view the six sense objects as illusions and transformations. May they decisively turn away from the objects of the five desires, and not give rise to deviant thoughts even in dreams. May they never be moved by internal and external conditions.
I vow that through the merit of repenting the eye faculty, may this eye see the pure Dharma bodies of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas in the ten directions without dualistic appearances;

I vow that through the merit of repenting the ear faculty, may these ears always hear the true Dharma spoken by the Buddhas and sages in the ten directions and respectfully practice according to the teachings;
I vow that through the merit of repenting the nose faculty, may this nose always smell the incense of the stage of Dharma realization, and abandon the foul stench of impurity in birth and death;
I vow that through the merit of repenting the tongue faculty, may this tongue always savor the joy of Dharma and the bliss of meditation, and not crave the blood and flesh of sentient beings;

I vow that through the merit of repenting the body faculty, may this body be clothed in the TathÄgata's robe, wear the armor of forbearance, lie on the bed of fearlessness, and sit on the seat of the four dhyÄnas;

May we, by the merit of repenting the faults of the mind, wish to perfect the ten contemplations and penetrate the five sciences, deeply contemplate the principle of the two truths and emptiness and equality, give rise to the ten wondrous practices from skillful wisdom, enter the flowing water of the Dharma and increase in brightness moment by moment, and manifest the great patience of non-arising of the Tathagata's great Dharma.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Bodhisattva of the Lotus Treasure on Retribution, Scroll 1. Baota entered a hell called the Fire Elephant Hell.

In that hell, there naturally appeared a fire elephant. The elephant's body was extremely long and large, and the elephant's body was burning with fire, smoke and flames coming out together, and the elephant's mouth and eyes were also burning with fire.

The sinners saw it as cramped and cried out in distress, unwilling to go forward. The prison guards and yaká¹£as grabbed them and put them on elephants. The elephants jumped and the sinners fell to the ground. The ground was on fire, burning their bodies. In a single day and night, they died a thousand times and were revived a thousand times, died ten thousand times and were revived ten thousand times. When they emerged from hell, if they were reborn as humans, their bodies would be incomplete, they would be eunuchs, hermaphrodites, or stone women.
Baota asked the horse-headed rÄká¹£asa:
What sins did these monks commit that they receive such punishments?
The rÄká¹£asa replied:

These monks received the Buddha's pure precepts but did not uphold them purely. They engaged in sexual activity and lacked proper deportment. Their bodies were impure, and they entered the Buddha's temple and gazed around, rubbing against the Buddha's image without a sense of shame.
For these reasons, they fell into hell and received such punishments.
When Baota heard this, he wept sorrowfully and left.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Buddhas' Names Sutra, Scroll 7
